title: Dick Durbin, Longtime Anti-Smoking Advocate, Turns Sights on Vaping
text:
WASHINGTON—Five days before the Trump administration moved to ban the sale of fruit- and candy-flavored vaping products, acting Food and Drug Administration commissioner Norman E. “Ned” Sharpless received a sharply worded letter from Sen. Dick Durbin (D., Ill.).

The message: if Dr. Sharpless didn’t move to ban the flavored products in 10 days, Mr. Durbin would publicly demand his resignation.

The ban was announced Sept. 11 by President Trump, Dr. Sharpless and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar.

Close observers say Mr. Durbin’s persistence on the issue, along with mounting evidence of death and illness associated with vaping, has long been pivotal in advancing safety issues related to tobacco and nicotine.

“The real hero in this fight is Dick Durbin,” said David Kessler, the former FDA commissioner who served under both Presidents George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton. “There has been a fierceness and a persistence about Sen. Durbin and his staff.”

Dr. Sharpless, in a written statement, said, “We appreciate Sen. Durbin’s passion for the agency’s public health mission and we look forward to continuing to work with him to address this growing problem.”

While cigarette smoking has declined among teens, nearly 28% of high-school students this year reported using e-cigarettes at least once in the past 30 days, up from 21% last year, according to a recent federal study. On Friday, Mr. Durbin and three colleagues called on the FDA to ban all pod- and cartridge-based e-cigarettes, the type used most by minors—until they can be shown to benefit the public health.

Mr. Durbin is among a handful of lawmakers including Sens. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska), Sherrod Brown (D., Ohio), Richard Blumenthal (D., Conn.) and Patty Murray (D., Wash.) who have been urging stringent action on the flavored products for a year or more.

Mr. Durbin came away from a heated May conversation with Dr. Sharpless—audible outside the senator’s office—“disappointed and alarmed” at what he regarded as the agency’s inaction, the senator wrote in a follow-up letter to the commissioner.

Mr. Durbin’s aides said they once visited a vape store near his Senate office that sold liquid flavors like gummy bear, whipped cream and tutti-frutti that they believe are targeted toward children.

He expressed his frustration with the FDA’s acting commissioner by sending him a letter dated May 29 that quoted President Abraham Lincoln ’s famous missive to battle-shy Union general George McClellan: “If you do not want to use the Army, I should like to borrow it for a while.”

Mr. Durbin has since praised the administration for its plan to ban flavored electronic cigarettes.

Altria, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, invested almost $13 billion in e-cigarette company Juul. Some experts say in its early days Juul mirrored the tobacco industry’s promotional playbook in an effort to hook young people. Photo: Natalia V. Osipova/The Wall Street Journal

There are still those, in academia and elsewhere, who contend e-cigarettes can fill a positive role in getting smokers off combustible cigarettes.

“Despite some risks of nicotine dependence that can be mitigated but not eliminated, no credible evidence counters the assertion that noncombustible nicotine products will save lives if they displace smoking,” David B. Abrams of New York University and colleagues wrote in Preventive Medicine last year.

Dr. Abrams, while praising Mr. Durbin for his efforts against cigarette smoking, said the senator had nonetheless been “slow to recognize the potential of vaping products for saving lives” of cigarette smokers.

Such views have largely been drowned out lately amid the hundreds of respiratory illnesses and eight deaths linked to vaping, possibly caused by substances like vitamin E acetate and THC in black-market products.

Mr. Durbin, 74 years old, was a high school sophomore when his father, a two-pack-a-day smoker, died of lung cancer. The senator says that, to this day, he still tenses up when he hears someone cough.

So when he was elected to the House of Representatives in 1982, one of his first efforts was to take on Big Tobacco, despite advice to the contrary from multiple colleagues. Once, waiting for a flight from Phoenix to Chicago, he learned he was assigned a middle seat in a smoking section. He asked an airline worker whether she could do anything about this. “No,” she said, “but you can.”

His first successful major legislative foray against the tobacco industry was to get smoking banned on flights of less than two hours—deciding on that limit after a senior colleague told him he could last only two hours without a smoke.

By 2014, Mr. Durbin along with then- Rep. Henry A. Waxman (D., Calif.), Sens. Blumenthal, Brown and others, commissioned a staff report on e-cigarettes noting that sales of the products were promoted at events “many of which appear to be youth-oriented.”

He and colleagues have often continued to be out front of the FDA as it considered more regulation of tobacco and e-cigarettes. For instance, in April 2016, they pressed the Obama administration to finish a so-called deeming rule granting the FDA power over e-cigarettes and other tobacco products.

That happened soon after. In 2018, the FDA’s then-commissioner, Scott Gottlieb, required e-cigarette manufacturers to submit plans on how they would curb sales to youngsters.

In the view of Mr. Durbin and Ms. Murkowski, that wasn’t enough. Because of a sharp uptake in youth vaping, the senators called on the agency to outright ban flavors, like blue razz candy and chocolate cupcake, that appealed to children.

“There are other leaders on this issue,” said Matthew Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, “but among active members of Congress, no one has been more consistently involved than Dick Durbin.”

Write to Thomas M. Burton at tom.burton@wsj.com
description: One of the driving forces behind the U.S. government’s crackdown on vaping is Sen. Dick Durbin, arguably the tobacco industry’s archenemy in Washington.
